title: Top educator has radical vision for students

"People will increasingly move in and out of vocational education, higher education and microcredentialling and industry-provided training.

"What we are doing at schools has not caught up with the world young people are entering."

Dr Shergold said he supported the idea of students doing training courses at school but was disappointed that employers did not rate school training classes as highly as training done by TAFE or private providers.

All of this was out of kilter with employer demands.

Following the Joyce Review there was potential for a national partnership agreement in which the states would work together to co-ordinate the training sector.

There was evidence that some students would choose to do individual certificate courses without getting a degree but still be satisfied with what they'd learned.

This idea would eventually spread to the university sector where it was possible the formal "named" degree would cease to exist.

"I don't think it's impossible in the next decade to have a situation where people leave school and, with flexibility and hopefully career advice, choose a variety of courses that are offered by TAFEs, universities and private providers, and start to put together their own educational passports.

"Students are already starting to do that. They're voting with their feet.

"I think the status of a named degree will last for some time but increasingly employers will say 'just tell us what your education has been'."

Dr Shergold agreed there were serious inequities on fees with most basic training courses not attracting any fee subsidy, whereas university students could switch on a concessional loan whenever they wanted.

There should be a better explanation to final-year students that doing an apprenticeship meant not only they got paid to study but got a qualification without a HECS debt.

"I don't know what is the behavioural economics of how you make those choices. At one level you could make a strong argument that it's very attractive to be an apprentice."

Dr Shergold spoke to The Australian Financial Review after the controversial interim report into the NSW curriculum was published. This was hailed by Premier Gladys Berejiklian as going "back to basics". But its author, Geoff Masters, said his proposed changes "preference deeper conceptual understanding over shallower coverage of extensive factual and procedural detail".

Professor Masters expressed misgivings about the ATAR (Australian Tertiary Admissions Rank), which he said was an inadequate measure of 13 years of schooling.

"A long-term reform agenda for the senior years of school will be a curriculum less focused on the sometimes narrow needs of particular post-school destinations and more focused on providing every student with the broad knowledge, skills and attributes they for learning, life and work," he wrote.

Dr Shergold said more and more ministers and senior bureaucrats were expressing concern about the ATAR.

Professor Shergold said ATAR was in the target zone for reform but he was not sure if it should be ditched altogether. Peter Rae

"It is a very curious way in a single score of assessing the capability of someone leaving school.

"We are the only country which uses a single number queuing device. It was designed when there was greater demand for access to university."

ATAR was in the target zone for reform but he was not sure if it should be ditched altogether. But an increasingly number of universities were saying they would not rely on ATAR.

The Noonan Review of the Australian Qualifications Framework was released late in the week, proposing a simplified system of degrees and greater harmonisation of training and university.

Author Peter Noonan said qualifications in future should be measured in hours studied, not years, and should be compiled by students depending on their needs.

Dr Shergold, a former secretary of the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet, said his review came in the middle of a large number of school and post-school reviews. He described it as an area in which a lot of issues were overlapping.

"I would prefer that when people leave school, perhaps with a leaving certificate and in that or alongside it a much greater profile of the 'learnings' that they had taken inside the classroom and outside. I like the idea of a learning profile."
description: Break with the distinction between university and training and let students choose their own path.
